docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Welcome to Grid Adventure: Variant 1 (V1)

This documentation includes a Player Guide to get you started with the game as well as an Agent documentation to start developing your agent to play the game.

Use the tabs above to navigate to the guides and start gridding!

docs.title: Action
docs.text: The Action enum defines all available player actions.

docs.title: Actions
docs.text: Index Action Description 0 UP Move up 1 DOWN Move down 2 LEFT Move left 3 RIGHT Move right 4 USE_KEY Unlock adjacent locked entity with matching key 5 PICK_UP Collect items at current tile 6 WAIT Do nothing (advance turn)

docs.title: Use Case
docs.text:
Actions are primarily used with the step function of GridAdventureEnv. 

# Import
from grid_adventure.actions import Action

# Using Action enum with the environment
obs, reward, terminated, truncated, info = env.step(Action.UP)

# Using integer index
obs, reward, terminated, truncated, info = env.step(0)  # UP

docs.title: Agent Class
docs.text:
The Agent class serves as the API for interacting with Grid Adventure V1. It comprises two mandatory functions and two optional functions for debugging purposes.

Function Description __init__(self) -> None Initialization function step(self, state: GridState \| ImageObservation) -> Action Step function parse(self, obs: ImageObservation) -> Action Function responsible for generating an Action based on a game representation. def parse(self, obs: ImageObservation) -> GridState Optional function utilized in GridPlay to aid in visualizing what your agent perceives. def info(self) -> dict[str, Any] Optional function utilized in GridPlay to provide any information about your agent.

docs.title: Initialization Function
docs.text:
__init__(self) -> None

This initialization function is executed once when instantiating the agent class.

Tips: Utilize this function to declare any internal variables utilized by your agent.

docs.title: Step Function
docs.text:
step(self, state: GridState | ImageObservation) -> Action

This step function is invoked within the main agent-environment loop. Your implementation of this function serves as the “brain” of your agent, enabling it to make decisions regarding the next action based on the current observation.

docs.title: Parse Function
docs.text:
parse(self, obs: ImageObservation) -> GridState (Optional)

If implemented, it will be invoked by the Grid Play at every step to render what your agent currently sees, i.e., the parsed GridState representation from ImageObservation. This allows you to identify and correct errors in predicting the GridState from the ImageObservation.

You may find your agent's vision in the bottom right corner of the screen.

In the provided example, we observe the actual grid in the blue square and the agent’s vision in the red square. From here, we can see that the agent mistakenly believes there’s a box in the grid.

docs.title: Info Function
docs.text:
info(self) -> dict[str, Any] (Optional)

If implemented, Grid Play will display the information in the dictionary format shown below during each turn.

This allows you to view the internal variables of your agent at every step.

docs.title: Game Representation
docs.text: Grid Adventure V1 operates as a turn based game. Players are supplied with a snapshot of a turn of the game. Players then return an action, which is then used to generate the snapshot of the game after the action is made.

docs.title: Representation types
docs.text:
There are three representations of a game snapshot.

Representation Type Description GridState A grid based representation using a 2D Array. This is the most intuitive representation. ImageObservation An RGBA Image representation using a 3D Array, with additional info stored in an information dictionary State An Immutable world state. This is the most comprehensive, but low level representation

Note

There is no built-in mapping function between GridState and ImageObservation representations. If required, agents will need to build the mapping themselves.

Note

The Capstone Project can be solved without using the State representation.

docs.title: GridAdventureEnv
docs.text: GridAdventureEnv is the main environment that runs the Grid Adventure V1 game. It implements the Gymnasium API, providing a standard interface for agents to interact with the game.

docs.title: Constructor Parameters
docs.text:
Parameter Type Default Description initial_state_fn Callable[..., State] required Function that generates the initial internal game state render_mode str "rgb_array" Rendering mode observation_type str "image" or "gridstate" This determines if the game representation returned is of image (ImageObservation class) or gridstate (GridState class)

Note: For more details about ImageObservation class and GridState class, please refer to Game Representation.

docs.title: Methods
docs.text: Method Returns Description GridAdventureEnv.reset(seed, options) tuple[Observation, dict] Resets the internal game state and returns the game representation GridAdventureEnv.step(action) tuple[Observation, float, bool, bool, dict] Applies one action, and returns the game representation GridAdventureEnv.render() PILImage or None Renders the current state. Refer to Image Rendering GridAdventureEnv.close() None Releases resources

docs.title: GridState Representation
docs.text: The GridState Representation is a grid centric representation, that is easiest for players to follow

docs.title: GridState Attributes
docs.text:
The GridState class has 3 categories of attributes:

  • Overall Configuration
  • Grid Structure
  • Game Status

docs.title: Overall Configuration
docs.text: Attribute Type Description width int Grid width in tiles height int Grid height in tiles movement BaseMovement Movement function configuration objective BaseObjective Win/lose condition configuration seed int or None RNG seed for deterministic behavior

docs.title: Grid Structure
docs.text: Attribute Type Description grid list[list[list[BaseEntity]]] Grid representation where grid[x][y] is a list of entities at that cell

docs.title: Game Status
docs.text: Attribute Type Default Description turn int 0 Current turn number score int 0 Cumulative score win bool False True if the objective is met lose bool False True if the losing condition is met message str or None None Optional status message for display turn_limit int or None None Maximum turns allowed

docs.title: Available Methods
docs.text:
Method Returns Description GridState.add(pos, obj) None Place an entity at position (x, y) GridState.add_many(items) None Places multiple entities from list of (pos, obj) tuples GridState.remove(pos, obj) bool Removes a specific entity by identity; returns True if found GridState.remove_if(pos, predicate) int Remove entities where predicate(obj) is True; returns number of entities removed GridState.move_obj(from_pos, obj, to_pos) bool Move entity between cells; returns True if successful GridState.clear_cell(pos) int Remove all entities from cell; returns count GridState.objects_at(pos) list[BaseEntity] Return shallow copy of entities at position step(gridState, action) GridState Generates a new GridState with action to_state(gridState) State Converts mutable GridState to immutable State

Note: pos is of class Position, represented as a (int, int) Note: obj is of class BaseEntity, parent class of all Entities. For more details about entities, please refer to Entity Classes.

docs.title: Entity List
docs.text:
There are a total of 14 entities that can be present on the grid. To view the appearance and interactions between the entities, refer to the Player Guide.

All entities have an appearance.name attribute, which is a string describing the entity. It can be used to determine the entities present in each cell of the grid. Each entity below is given with its entity class name as well as appearance name in brackets.

Note

When rendering the grid, each entity’s appearance name is used to determine which image to display. By default, images are loaded from the DEFAULT_ASSET_ROOT defined in grid_adventure.rendering, which provides public assets from Grid Adventure V1. A mapping from appearance name is also defined as IMAGE_MAP in the same package.

AgentEntity ("human")

This is the entity controlled by the user. The Agent contains additional attributes and methods.

Attribute Type Description health Health Class Health to give the agent, constitutes Max and current health inventory_list list[BaseEntity] List of Entity that represents the Agent's inventory status_list list[BaseEntity] List of Entity that represents the statuses active on the agent Available Methods Inputs Description set_health health: int Sets the agent's health

LavaEntity ("lava")

WallEntity ("wall")

BoxEntity ("box")

CoinEntity ("coin")

GemEntity ("gem")

KeyEntity ("key")

LockedDoorEntity ("locked")

UnlockedDoorEntity ("opened")

SpeedPowerUpEntity ("boots")

ShieldPowerUpEntity ("shield")

PhasingPowerUpEntity ("ghost")

ExitEntity ("exit")

FloorEntity ("floor")

docs.title: ImageObservation Representation
docs.text:
The ImageObservation representation is created by Grid Adventure. It contains a 3D image array with additional information in a dictionary.

For more information on how the image is rendered, refer to Image Rendering.

docs.title: ImageObservation Attribute Hierarchy
docs.text:
The ImageObservation Class represents the game snapshot as a dictionary with the following hierarchy.

ImageObservation: TypedDict
├── image: ndarray[H, W, 4] (uint8)
│   └── RGBA pixel data for the rendered grid
│
└── info: InfoDict # Dictionary subclass
    │
    ├── agent: AgentInfo # Dictionary subclass
    │   │
    │   ├── health: HealthInfo # Dictionary subclass
    │   │   ├── current_health: int (-1 if missing)
    │   │   └── max_health: int (-1 if missing)
    │   │
    │   ├── effects: list[EffectEntry]
    │   │   └── [each entry]
    │   │       ├── id: int
    │   │       ├── type: str ("" | "IMMUNITY" | "PHASING" | "SPEED")
    │   │       ├── limit_type: str ("" | "TIME" | "USAGE")
    │   │       ├── limit_amount: int (-1 if unlimited)
    │   │       └── multiplier: int (-1 if not SPEED)
    │   │
    │   └── inventory: list[InventoryItem]
    │       └── [each item]
    │           ├── id: int
    │           ├── type: str ("key" | "gem" | "coin" | "item")
    │           └── appearance_name: str ("" if unknown)
    │
    ├── status: StatusInfo # Dictionary subclass
    │   ├── score: int
    │   ├── phase: str ("ongoing" | "win" | "lose")
    │   └── turn: int
    │
    ├── config: ConfigInfo # Dictionary subclass
    │   ├── movement: str (movement function name)
    │   ├── objective: str (objective function name)
    │   ├── seed: int (-1 if None)
    │   ├── width: int
    │   ├── height: int
    │   └── turn_limit: int (-1 if unlimited)
    │
    └── message: str ("" if None)

docs.title: Image Usage Example
docs.text:
from grid_adventure.gym_env import GridAdventureEnv
from grid_adventure.examples.maze import generate
import numpy as np

env = GridAdventureEnv(
    initial_state_fn=generate,
    width=9,
    height=9
)
obs, info = env.reset()

image = obs["image"]  # Shape: (H, W, 4), dtype: uint8

# Get image dimensions
height, width, channels = image.shape

# Save as PNG
from PIL import Image
pil_image = Image.fromarray(image)
pil_image.save("screenshot.png")

# Display with matplotlib
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.imshow(image)
plt.axis("off")
plt.show()

docs.title: InfoDict Usage Example
docs.text:
from grid_adventure.gym_env import GridAdventureEnv
from grid_adventure.examples.maze import generate

env = GridAdventureEnv(
    initial_state_fn=generate,
    width=9,
    height=9
)
obs, info = env.reset()

# Access the rendered image data
image = obs["image"]  # shape: (H, W, 4), dtype: uint8

# Access agent health
current_health = obs["info"]["agent"]["health"]["current_health"]
max_hp = obs["info"]["agent"]["health"]["max_health"]

# Check game phase
phase = obs["info"]["status"]["phase"]  # "ongoing", "win", or "lose"

# Get active effects
for effect in obs["info"]["agent"]["effects"]:
    print(f"Effect {effect['type']}: {effect['limit_amount']} remaining")

# Check inventory
for item in obs["info"]["agent"]["inventory"]:
    print(f"Item: {item['type']} (id={item['id']})")

docs.title: Image Rendering
docs.text:
The rendered image represents the current game state as a 2D grid. Each grid cell may contain multiple entities, which are populated in order to produce the final image. For more information on the different entities and their appearances, please refer to the Player Guide.

An example of a rendered grid is shown below.

docs.title: Initial State
docs.text:
• At the start of the game, entities do not overlap.
  • The only exception is Floor, which may exist beneath any entity.

docs.title: During Gameplay
docs.text: Overlaps may occur when the Agent moves onto a tile containing other entities.

docs.title: Agent with collectible items
docs.text:
When the Agent occupies the same cell as a collectible item:

  • The Agent is rendered normally
  • The collectible item is shrunk and displayed in the top-left corner of the cell

docs.title: Agent with background entities
docs.text:
Floor, Lava, Exit, and UnlockedDoor are background entities.

When the Agent occupies the same cell as a background entity:

  • The background entity remains visible
  • The Agent is rendered in front of it

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Welcome to Grid Adventure V1 Agent Documentation.

This agent documentation is designed to help you understand the technical aspects of the game and get you started with developing your own agent:

  • Grid Adventure Environment — The environment in which the game is run
  • Game Representation — How the game is represented and how players can interact with the game
  • Action Class — Actions that the Agent can take in a turn
  • Agent Class — Agent class to be implemented to play the game

Dive into each section to master the game and start building your agent!

docs.title: State Representation
docs.text:
The state representation is the internal representation used by the Grid Adventure game. It stores information in various attributes, tracked by EntityID of each Entity. It is the most comprehensive of the 3 representations, and is used to generate the GridState and ImageObservation representations.

WARNING ON STATE REPRESENTATION

The Capstone Project can be solved without using the State Representation, however the State Representation is included for a lower level access to the representation.

docs.title: State Attributes
docs.text:
The state Class represents the Game snapshot with the following 4 types of attributes.

  • Grid Configuration
  • Effect Configuration
  • Property Components
  • Game Status

docs.title: Grid Configuration
docs.text: Attribute Type Description width int Grid width in tiles height int Grid height in tiles movement BaseMovement Movement functions allowed objective BaseObjective Objective of the grid

docs.title: Effect Components
docs.text:
All effect stores are of type PMap[EntityID, Component]. Note: PMap is an immutable dictionary, standard dictionary methods are available.

Attribute Mapped Component Description immunity Immunity Damage immunity effects phasing Phasing Pass-through-walls effects speed Speed Movement multiplier effects time_limit TimeLimit Effect duration (remaining steps) usage_limit UsageLimit Effect uses (remaining count)

docs.title: Property Components
docs.text:
All property stores are of type PMap[EntityID, Component]. Note: PMap is an immutable dictionary, standard dictionary methods are available.

Attribute Mapped Component Description agent Agent Player-controlled entities appearance Appearance Visual rendering properties blocking Blocking Obstacles that block movement collectible Collectible Items that can be picked up collidable Collidable Entities triggering collision events cost Cost Entities that inflict movement cost damage Damage Entities that deal damage on contact dead Dead Dead/incapacitated entities exit Exit Grid exit points health Health Entity health (current/max) inventory Inventory Items held by entities key Key Keys that unlock Locked entities locked Locked Locked doors/entities position Position Entity grid positions pushable Pushable Entities that can be pushed requirable Requirable Must-collect items for objectives rewardable Rewardable Entities granting score rewards status Status Active status effects on entities

docs.title: Game Status
docs.text: Attribute Type Default Description turn int 0 Current turn number score int 0 Cumulative score win bool False True if objective met lose bool False True if losing condition met message str or None None Optional status message for display turn_limit int or None None Max turns allowed seed int or None None RNG seed for deterministic behavior

docs.title: Useful Methods
docs.text: Method Description state.description Property returning PMap of all non-empty state attributes from_state(state) Converts immutable State to mutable GridState

docs.title: Entities
docs.text: All effects and components are represented by Entities in the Grid Adventure game. Each entity is assigned a unique EntityID at creation. This EntityID is used to map to each attribute of the Entity.

docs.title: Entity Types
docs.text:
There are in general 5 types of Entities

Entity Types Description CollidableEntity Recognisable for possession of collidable attribute of Collidable class BlockingEntity Recognisable for possession of blocking attribute of Blocking class PushableEntity Recognisable for possession of pushable attribute of Pushable class CollectibleEntity Recognisable for possession of collectible attribute of Collectible class Others All other entities

docs.title: Collidable Entities
docs.text:
These are entities which can pass through each other but trigger interactions when they do. These entities are recognisable for possession of collidable attribute of Collidable class.

There are in total 2 relevant Collidable Entities.

  • AgentEntity
  • LavaEntity

docs.title: AgentEntity
docs.text:
This is the entity controlled by the user.

Attribute Type Description health Health Class Health to give the agent, constitutes Max and current health inventory_list Inventory Class List of Entity that represents the Agent's inventory status_list Status Class List of Entity that represents the statuses active on the agent Available Methods Inputs Description set_health health: int Sets the agent's health

docs.title: LavaEntity
docs.text: This is a damaging entity that the agent can walk through.

docs.title: BlockingEntity
docs.text:
These are entities which cannot be passed through by Collidable Entities. These entities are recognisable for possession of blocking attribute of Blocking class.

There are in total 3 relevant BlockingEntity.

  • WallEntity
  • LockedDoorEntity
  • BoxEntity

docs.title: PushableEntity
docs.text:
These are entities which are pushable by the Agent. These entities are recognisable for possession of pushable attribute of Pushable class.

There is 1 relevant pushable entity, BoxEntity

docs.title: WallEntity
docs.text: This is a wall entity that the agent cannot walk through or push. The wall entity has no attributes.

docs.title: BoxEntity
docs.text:
This is a pushable blocking entity that the agent can push but not walk through. The box entity has no attributes.

Note: that the box is both Blocking and a Pushable Entity

docs.title: LockedDoorEntity
docs.text:
This is a blocking entity that the agent cannot push through or push. This entity becomes a UnlockedDoorEntity, when a KeyEntity is used on it

Attribute Type Description locked Locked Class Locked door that can be unlocked by a Key

Note: Each grid can have multiple key - door pairs. Any key can be used to unlock a door, but each key can only be used once.

docs.title: CollectibleEntity
docs.text:
These are entities which are collectible by the agent. These entities are recognisable for possession of collectible attribute of Collectible class.

There are in total 6 relevant CollectibleEntity.

  • CoinEntity
  • GemEntity
  • KeyEntity
  • SpeedPowerUpEntity
  • ShieldPowerUpEntity
  • PhasingPowerUpEntity

docs.title: CoinEntity
docs.text:
This is an optional collectible that provides a score when collected by the agent.

Attribute Type Description rewardable Rewardable Class The score provided for picking up the coin

Note: Score received for collecting a coin is fixed at 5.

docs.title: GemEntity
docs.text: This is a compulsory collectible to be collected by agent before it can enter the exit. The GemEntity has no attributes.

docs.title: KeyEntity
docs.text:
This is a collectible required to unlock a LockedDoorEntity

Attribute Type Description key Key Class Key class that can be used to unlock LockedDoorEntity

Note: Any key present in the grid can be used to unlock a door, but each key can only be used once.

docs.title: SpeedPowerUpEntity
docs.text:
This is a collectible power-up granting agent the ability to walk 2 tiles in 1 turn for a duration of time.

Attribute Type Description speed Speed Class Speed class that saves multiplier, indicating speed up provided time_limit TimeLimit Class TimeLimit class that saves amount, indicating number of turns powerup is active

Note: Time limit is a constant at 5 steps.

docs.title: ShieldPowerUpEntity
docs.text:
This is a collectible power-up granting agent immunity while walking on damaging tiles for 5 uses.

Attribute Type Description usage_limit UsageLimit Class UsageLimit class that shows durability of the shield

Note: Usage limit is a constant at 5 uses.

docs.title: PhasingPowerUpEntity
docs.text:
This is a collectible power-up granting agent ability to walk through BlockingEntity for a duration of time.

Attribute Type Description time_limit TimeLimit Class TimeLimit class that saves amount, indicating number of turns powerup is active

Note: Time limit is a constant at 5 steps.

docs.title: Other Entities
docs.text: These Entities extend directly from BaseEntity. They are either non interactable entities which are purely for aesthetic purposes, or in the case of ExitEntity & FloorEntity, entities with special purposes.

docs.title: ExitEntity
docs.text: This serves as the final tile the agent has to reach to complete the objective. The ExitEntity has no other attributes.

docs.title: FloorEntity
docs.text: Floor entities are not interactable with the agent.

docs.title: UnlockedDoorEntity
docs.text: UnlockedDoorEntity is not interactable with agent and serves only an aesthetic purpose. It is the unlocked version of the LockedDoorEntity. The UnlockedDoorEntity has no attributes.

docs.title: Usage Example
docs.text: Use the code examples given below to familiarise yourself on the State representation and explore the different components.

docs.title: Useful Operations
docs.text:
• Get agent ID 

    next(iter(state.agent.keys()), None)

  • Lookup components by EntityId 

    state.position.get(eid)
eid in state.blocking

  • Iterate entities in a cell Invert state.position to obtain a mapping of: 

    Position -> [EntityID]

  • Sparse debug view 

    state.description
    Returns a PMap containing only populated component stores.

  • Apply an action 

    step(State, Action) -> State

docs.title: Full Example
docs.text:
from grid_adventure.step import step

# Creation of the grid still requires use of GridState
gridstate = GridState(width=4, height=3, movement=MOVEMENTS["cardinal"], objective=OBJECTIVES["collect_gems_and_exit"], seed=0,)
for y in range(gridstate.height):
    for x in range(gridstate.width):
        gridstate.add((x, y), FloorEntity())
# Add an agent entity, box and exit to the grid
gridstate.add((0, 1), AgentEntity())
gridstate.add((1,1), BoxEntity())
gristate.add((3,1), ExitEntity())

# Convert GridState to the immutable State representation
state = to_state(gridstate)

# state.description contains only populated component stores
# (e.g. position, agent, blocking, etc.)

# state.position maps EntityID -> (x, y) coordinates and can be used to locate entities in the grid

# Retrieve the agent's EntityID
agent_id = next(iter(state.agent.keys()))
box_entity_ids = list(state.pushable.keys()) # Find all entities that are pushable. Since only 1 box is added, it contains the entity id of the box
box_id = box_entity_ids[0]

# Look up current position
agent_position = state.position.get(agent_id) #(0,1)
box_position = state.position.get(box_id) #(1,1)

# Check whether the entity is considered blocking
is__agent_blocking = agent_id in state.blocking # False
is_box_blocking = box_id in state.blocking # True

# Apply an action using step. step returns a new State
state = step(state, Action.RIGHT)

# After stepping, the agent's position in state_3_1.position is updated
new_agent_position = state.position.get(agent_id) #(1,1)

docs.title: Entities
docs.text: All objects available in Grid Adventure V1 are shown below. Each entity is displayed in five slightly different visuals. Many other appearances exist that are similar but may differ subtly from those shown.

docs.title: Floor
docs.text: Floor is the basic tile of the grid. Other entities can also be present with floor tiles.

docs.title: Agent
docs.text:
Agent is the character that you will control and play as. It appears in the grid as a human. You will move around the grid, interact with objects and aim to complete the objective.

In 1 turn, the Agent can either move to an adjacent tile (up/down/left/right), pickup a item, use a key to unlock a door or simply do nothing (wait). The agent starts with some health points (up to 5) and the player loses if the HP drops to 0.

docs.title: Wall
docs.text: Walls can be present on the grid and blocks the agent from moving past them.

docs.title: Exit
docs.text: This is the final escape tile that the agent must reach to complete the objective.

docs.title: Coin
docs.text: Coin is a optional item that can be picked up on the grid. The agent may collect a coin to receive a reward of 5.

docs.title: Gem
docs.text: Gem is an item on the grid that needs to be picked up. If any gems are present, the agent must collect all of them before moving to the exit tile to complete the objective.

docs.title: Key
docs.text: Key is an optional item on the grid that can be picked up by the agent. A key is required to unlock a door. Any key can be used to unlock a door, but each key can only be used once.

docs.title: Door
docs.text: A locked door blocks the agent from moving past it. To unlock a door, the agent must first collect a key. Using the key while standing adjacent to the door unlocks it, turning it into an unlocked door. The agent can then pass freely through unlocked doors. Unlocked doors appear on the grid as shown below.

docs.title: Box
docs.text: Box is an item on the grid that can be moved by the agent. The agent can push a box in any direction onto a free tile. Boxes cannot be pushed onto walls, doors, or lava.

docs.title: Lava
docs.text: Lava tiles inflict damage to the agent. When the agent lands on lava, it takes 2 damage. The player loses if the agent's HP drops to 0.

docs.title: Powerups
docs.text: Powerups may also appear on the grid and can be picked up by the agent. They provide temporary boosts and are associated with either a turn or usage limit.

docs.title: Speed Powerup
docs.text:
The speed powerup allows the agent to move 2 tiles in 1 turn. It has a 5-turn limit. Note that the agent can still be blocked by any objects in its path.

Stacking

If the agent picks up a second speed powerup while one is active, they will both count down simultaneously. Thus, the powerup will expire 5 turns after the last one is picked up. The agent still moves 2 tiles in a turn, even if multiple speed powerups are active.

docs.title: Shield Powerup
docs.text:
Shield protects the agent from damage taken. It has a usage limit of 5. The shield is used once every time the agent lands on lava.

Stacking

If the agent picks up a second shield while one is active, they will be used one after the other. If the agent currently has an active shield with durability 2 and picks up a new shield, it will have 2 active shields, with durability 2 and 5 respectively. When the agent lands on lava, only the first one is used, leaving the agent with 2 active shields, with durability 1 and 5.

docs.title: Phasing Powerup
docs.text:
Phasing allows the agent to move through objects. It has a turn limit of 5. While the powerup is active, the agent can move through walls, doors and boxes. The agent does not take damage from lava as well.

Stacking

If the agent picks up a second phasing powerup while one is active, they will both count down simultaneously. Thus, the powerup will expire 5 turns after the last one is picked up.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Welcome to Grid Adventure V1 Player Guide.

Grid Adventure V1 is a flexible, grid‑based game in which you implement an agent that interacts with diverse gameplay mechanics to fulfil objectives.

The world is represented as a 2D grid made up of tiles. The agent can start at any location in the grid and must work towards collecting any gems, and reaching the exit tile.

This Player Guide is designed to help you understand every part of the game:

  • Entities — the objects you will encounter in the grid
  • Objectives — what you must accomplish to win the game
  • Movements — how the Agent moves and interacts with various objects

Dive into each section to master the game and start gridding!

docs.title: Basic movements
docs.text:
In a turn, the agent can move to an adjacent tile (Up/Down/Left/Right)

The example shows the agent performing basic movements.

docs.title: Collecting items
docs.text:
If the agent is on the same tile as any collectible items, the agent can use a turn to pick it up.

The example shows the agent picking up items such as keys, gems and coins.

docs.title: Key and Door
docs.text:
To unlock a door, the agent must first collect a key, then move to and unlock the door from an adjacent tile.

The example shows the agent collecting the key, then unlocking the door to be able to pass through.

docs.title: Box
docs.text:
To push a box, the agent must stand adjacent to it and move in the direction of the push.

The example shows the agent pushing the box aside to be able to reach the exit tile.

docs.title: Speed Powerup
docs.text:
Speed allows the agent to move 2 tiles in 1 turn. It lasts for 5 turns.

The example shows the agent movement once boots are picked up. Note that walls can still restrict the agent from moving 2 tiles. After 5 turns, the agent exhausts the powerup and returns to 1 tile per turn.

docs.title: Shield Powerup
docs.text:
Shield allows the agent to move through lava without taking damage. It has 5 uses.

In this example, the agent health has been set to 1, so the agent dies when stepping on lava without the shield.

In order to reach the exit, the agent can collect the shield powerup which allows it to safely pass through the lava.

docs.title: Phasing Powerup
docs.text:
Phasing powerup allows the agent to move through objects such as walls, doors and boxes. It lasts for 5 turns.

In this example, the agent collects the phasing powerup to pass through the walls and reach the exit tile.

docs.title: Objectives
docs.text:
The objective for Grid Adventure: V1 is to complete the following tasks:

  • If any gems are present in the grid, collect all of them
  • Move to the exit tile

docs.title: Optimal Solution
docs.text: An optimal solution achieves all objectives while maximising the total reward. There is no requirement to finish with nonnegative reward or maximum HP. To maximize rewards, the agent can either complete objectives in fewer turns or collect more coins.

docs.title: Reward
docs.text:
• Each turn taken by the agent incurs a reward of -3.
  • Each coin collected provides a reward of 5.
